titleStmt.title: Edited text of excerpts from the Chronicle

app.note: Spelling corrected to modern orthography.
Spelling corrected to modern orthography.
Emended to modern orthography.
Spelling corrected to modern orthography.
Spelling corrected to modern orthography.
Most witnesses have the post-classical \arm{եպիսկոպոսունք}; here we retain the more symmetrical \arm{եպիսկոպոսք}. (c.f. Karst p. 206.)
Preponderance of readings omit \arm{զ-}, but neither Karst nor Meillet suggest that is grammatical.
TODO check O
TODO check O
\arm{երերամ} is an attested variant of \arm{երերիմ}.
From \arm{աղէտանամ}.
K reads `they stood being gazed fixedly at by fear'
TODO check O ms
TODO check O ms
TODO check O
K's use of \arm{անկեալ} probably reflects the scribe's lack of context for the word \arm{դարձեալ} (`again').
Difference is between `in fearful sorrows' or `in this fearful sorrow'.
Lemma reflects standard spelling of the name.
Popular alternative (LHA) reads `tortures of Christ in/at the Crucifixion'.
Y reads `into the Jordan river'

A gives a number that tallies with the placement of this prophecy within the Chronicle, and is thus accepted. The others seem to suggest, no doubt thanks to lack of context, that Kozeṙn made an earlier prophecy in 471 (1022/3).
This reading comes from K and is almost certainly an emendation, but it is clear that some word is missing here, and the reading of HL is of no assistance.
Comma placement in HIDJLZW gives the reading `they lack hope for the future [and] fear of the judgment of God; true faith is disdained and done away with...'
G gives `they didn't believe in the admonition'.
The word for `faith' should be plural as a substantive, thus reading W is accepted.
Although HL is not generally to be preferred, here the scribe has restored the original verse in full. C.f. Matthew 22:11-14.

Together with the substantial variant above, DIJWZ (possibly together with C) gives `[saints]; this was the reason that the sun darkened. Those who stand for this nation henceforth will become deliverance from outsiders...' HL preserves `invasion' rather than `deliverance'; it is unclear which reading the scribe intended.
HL reading is `behold [all the nations of Christ's faithful] dwell.'
Punctuation in J reading gives `all creatures and the Persians and everyone tremble, and the foreign forces shall take flight'.
capitalize for new sentence
F reading is `Zion'.
capitalize start of sentence
The ambiguously abbreviated readings for this word are retained in the apparatus here and below.
There is no attested word \arm{իմաստ(ն)ագրութիւն}, but there is \arm{իմաստագործութիւն}. The variant readings may be based on that.
YVKJer form has \arm{աւգտակարիմ} - `they might find easily useful'. FX `they might easily do by slow degrees'.
Y is a grammatically better reading, but the evidence for \arm{զորս} is overwhelming.
This is a difficult reading. A clue may lie with G, but it cannot be accepted without access to the original manuscript.
K's reading is `again we frequent the same punishment...'
TODO some serious date problems here.
K reading is `the eras one after another' or `according to the eras'.
A reading is `skillful, artful'.
This is a corrupted quote of 1Cor 14:30, which reads `\arm{եթէ այլ ումեք որ նստիցին՝ յայտնեսցի, առաջինն լռեսցէ։}' The words \arm{յատենի ելցէ} have therefore been emended to \arm{յայտնեսցէ}.
Emendation corrects spelling of \arm{Ասորւոց}.
Jer variant says `shoots, offspring'.
KVJer reading is `I Matthew who am unworthy, with the mercy of God have spent many years...'
BX reading is `[already] collected in writing'.
K reading is `from the humble/inferior'.
K reading is `he declares/expresses useful work...'.
V reading is `hives of sins'; OX reading is `hives of sinners'.
K reading is `it stands praised/glorious before kings and princes'.
Readings ABO, as well as K, seem to agree on \arm{հարսնանան} (are wed), but that makes little sense in this context.
K is the more classically correct reading; this usage may have shifted in post-classical times.
AB reading gives `in its wondrous work of nature'; also plausible, but marginally less likely.
K reading is `other stouter nations'.
O reading could be synonym, with connotation `solidly'
The reading in B is garbled, and could also be \arm{կամ(պ)?ամուռն}. None of these possibilities seem to make sense. TODO check MAD
K reads `which [things] we read in this history'.

X reads `captured'. K has a substantially different reading here: `...and things that we sought in archives, and things that we investigated through unceasing pursuit of conversation with old men; therefore having collected so many things through a great deal of work I wrote them [down].'
K reads `I am/stand to find'.
Corrected spelling to canonical form.
This is canonically spelled \arm{փութոյ}.
DEFGX variant is `natural'.
JerKV reading is `it was in the year'.

The clue to the reading here is the freqent occurrence of \arm{ի՟ե՟անց}; the \arm{-անց} ending is grammatically valid for \arm{եւթն} but not \arm{հինգ}, suggesting that the original reading was in fact \arm{է՟} and not \arm{ե՟}.
K reads `passed'.
B reads \arm{յաւժարական։ մտաւք և սկսաք} - `willingly; and mindfully I began'
B reading, though in a minority, would seem to make more grammatical sense.
JerKV reading is `rebuke'.
B reading is a synonym.
F reading gives `we whistled'.
F reading gives `Bark'.
Emended to \arm{ցհարսն} for symmetry with later \arm{ծերսն}.
C.f. Deuteronomy 32:7. K's use of \arm{պատմեսցեն} here, and \arm{ցծերս} below, follows certain versions of the biblical text. TODO check Zohrab
FX reading is `preoccupations'.
K reading is a synonym.
